io.hekate.core

Interface Hekate

  • All Superinterfaces:
    HekateSupport

    public interface Hekate
extends HekateSupport
    « start hereMain entry point to Hekate services.

    Overview

    Hekate is a Java library for cluster communications and computing. It provides a number of services for building a cluster of interconnected processes, messaging and execution of distributed tasks. This interface is the main entry point for accessing the following services:

    • ClusterService - manages dynamic information about the cluster members and provides support for application to get notified upon cluster membership changes
    • MessagingService - provides high-level API for asynchronous messaging among the cluster nodes with built-in failover and load balancing
    • LockService - provides support for distributed locks
    • ElectionService - provides support for cluster-wide leader election (aka cluster singleton)
    • CoordinationService - provides support for implementing distributed coordination protocols
    • LocalMetricsService - provides support for managing user-defined metrics
    • ClusterMetricsService - provides access to metrics of remote cluster nodes
    • NetworkService - provides configuration options and low level API for network communications
    • CodecService - provides abstraction layer of data serialization API
    • InjectionService - provides support for dependency injection
    • JmxService - provides JXM support

    Instantiation

    Instances of this interface can be constructed by calling the HekateBootstrap.join() method (or its asynchronous equivalent). This method creates a new Hekate instance and joins it to the cluster. It is possible to create and run multiple Hekate instances within a single JVM. Each such instance is an independent cluster node with its own set of resources (threads, sockets, etc).

    If the application runs on top of the Spring Framework, then you can use the Spring Framework integration provided by the HekateSpringBootstrap class (please see its documentation for more details).

    • Java
    • Spring XSD
    • Spring bean
    
// Start new node with all configuration parameters set to their default values.
Hekate hekate = new HekateBootstrap()
    .withNodeName("my-node")
    .withClusterName("my-cluster")
    .join();
    Note: This example requires Spring Framework integration (see HekateSpringBootstrap). 
    
<beans xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"
    xmlns:h="http://www.hekate.io/spring/hekate-core"
    xmlns="http://www.springframework.org/schema/beans"
    xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.springframework.org/schema/beans
        http://www.springframework.org/schema/beans/spring-beans.xsd
        http://www.hekate.io/spring/hekate-core
        http://www.hekate.io/spring/hekate-core.xsd">

    <!-- Node with all configuration options set to their default values. -->
    <h:node id="hekate" name="my-node" cluster="my-cluster"/>

</beans>
    Note: This example requires Spring Framework integration (see HekateSpringBootstrap). 
    
<beans xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"
    xmlns="http://www.springframework.org/schema/beans"
    xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.springframework.org/schema/beans
        http://www.springframework.org/schema/beans/spring-beans.xsd">

    <!-- Node with all configuration options set to their default values. -->
    <bean id="hekate" class="io.hekate.spring.bean.HekateSpringBootstrap">
        <property name="nodeName" value="my-node"/>
        <property name="clusterName" value="my-cluster"/>
    </bean>

</beans>

    Configuration

    Configuration options for the Hekate instance can be specified via properties of the HekateBootstrap class. This class provides bean-style properties with getters/setters (for Spring Framework XML files) as well as fluent-style API for programmatic configuration via Java code.

    The key configuration options are:

    • Cluster name
    • Node name
    • Node properties
    • Node roles
    • Serialization codec
    • Services to be provided by the node
    • Plugins that should run within the node

    Other noticeable configuration options are:

    • Network address and port
    • Cluster discovery and validation
    • Cluster failure and split-brain detection

    Services configuration

    Each service has a configurable ServiceFactory that can be registered within a HekateBootstrap instance via HekateBootstrap.setServices(List) or HekateBootstrap.withService(ServiceFactory) methods. The code example below shows how different services can be configured: 

    
// Configure and start new node.
Hekate hekate = new HekateBootstrap()
    // Configure services.
    .withService(NetworkServiceFactory.class, net -> {
        net.setPort(10012); // Network port of this node.
        net.setPortRange(100); // Auto-increment range if port is busy.
    })
    .withService(ClusterServiceFactory.class, cluster -> {
        cluster.setGossipInterval(1000); // Gossip once per second.
        cluster.setSpeedUpGossipSize(100); // Speed up convergence if cluster is <= 100 nodes.
    })
    // ...some other services...
    .join();

// Get cluster service.
ClusterService cluster = hekate.cluster();

    Lifecycle

    The lifecycle of each Hekate instance is controlled in the following methods:

    • initialize() - initializes this instance and all of services.
    • join() - initializes this instance (if not initialized yet) and joins the cluster.
    • leave() - leaves the cluster and then terminates this instance. This is the recommended way to shutdown gracefully.
    • terminate() - terminates this instance, bypassing the cluster leave protocol (i.e. remote nodes will notice that this node left the cluster only based on their failure detection settings). In general, it is recommended to use graceful shutdown and use this method for abnormal termination (f.e. in case of unrecoverable error) or for testing purposes to emulate failures of cluster nodes.

    Each instance of Hekate goes through the following stages of the life cycle:

    • Hekate.State.DOWN - initial state
    • Hekate.State.INITIALIZING - node is initializing its services.
    • Hekate.State.INITIALIZED - node is initialized and is ready to start joining the cluster.
    • Hekate.State.JOINING - node successfully discovered a seed node and started joining the cluster.
    • Hekate.State.UP - node successfully joined the cluster and is ready to perform user operations.
    • Hekate.State.LEAVING - node started leaving the cluster.
    • Hekate.State.TERMINATING - node left the cluster and started terminating all of its services. Once this stage is completed then node will go back to the Hekate.State.DOWN state.

    Current state of the Hekate instance can be inspected via state() method. State changes can be monitored by registering a listener via addListener(LifecycleListener) method.

    See Also:
    HekateBootstrap

      • setAttribute

        <A> A setAttribute(String name,
                   Object value)
        Sets the attribute that should be associated with this Hekate instance.

        Note that such attributes are NOT cluster-wide and are not visible to other nodes of the cluster. Please see the ClusterNode.properties() method for cluster-wide properties support.

        Type Parameters:
        A - Attribute type.
        Parameters:
        name - Attribute name.
        value - Attribute value (if null then attribute of that name will be removed).
        Returns:
        Old attribute value or null.

      • getAttribute

        Type Parameters:

        Parameters:
        name - Attribute name.
        Returns:
        Attribute value or null if there is no such attribute.

        Returns:
        Future of this operation.

      • initialize

        Hekate initialize()
           throws InterruptedException,
                  HekateFutureException
        Synchronously initializes this instance without joining to the cluster..

        This method is simply a shortcut for the following sequence of method calls: 

        
hekate.initializeAsync().get();

        Returns:
        This instance.
        Throws:
        HekateFutureException - If failure occurred during initialization.
        InterruptedException - If thread gets interrupted while awaiting for completion of this operation.
        See Also:
        initializeAsync()

      • terminateAsync

        TerminateFuture terminateAsync()
        Asynchronously terminates this instance.

        Note that this method bypasses the cluster leave protocol and remote nodes will notice that this node left the cluster only based on the failure detection settings. In general it is recommended to use graceful shutdown and use this method for abnormal termination (f.e. in case of unrecoverable error) or for testing purposes to emulate failures of cluster nodes.

        The TerminateFuture object returned by this method can be used to obtain the result of this operation.

        Returns:
        This instance.
